Graphical abstract Silica-coated carbon fibers were prepared via a modified hydrothermal method with three separate catalysts synthesized by changing the sequence of Ni and SiO2 precursor addition to the carbon fiber and the as-prepared catalysts were utilized in the CO2 reforming methane reaction. It is found that the addition order of SiO2 and Ni precursors governed catalyst performance, where the addition of Ni and SiO2 precursors simultaneously (SiO2Ni@CF) has led to high stability for long-term operation at 700 °C. Particularly, CO2 conversion rate over SiO2Ni@CF catalyst was maintained at approximately 85 % after 24 h. The superior performance of SiO2Ni@CF is attributed to the formation of Ni phyllosilicate species. Simultaneous Ni-SiO2 addition facilitated a decrease in the particle size of the active Ni deposits via a confinement effect. The confinement effect constrained the reduced Ni particles to a lamellar phyllosilicate structure which introduced greater activity and an enhanced resistance to metal sintering. Keywords CO2 reforming of methane Carbon fiber Hydrothermal Coating Phyllosilicate Confinement 1 Introduction Continued industrialization and population growth has seen a rapid increase in energy consumption with time and will continue to increase into the future [1]. Nowadays, society remains over-reliant on traditional fossil fuels for meeting its energy demands. Fossil fuel combustion produces a large amount of CO2, causing a serious greenhouse effect. Finding new clean energy sources while increasing CO2 removal is considered as an effective approach to combating these issues [2]. CO2 reforming of methane (CRM - Eq. 1), can consume two of the primary greenhouse gases, CO2 and CH4, to produce syngas which is a feedstock in many chemical production processes such as the Fischer-Tropsch preparation of alcohols [3]. With respect to the catalysts applied in CRM, noble metal-based catalysts with high catalytic performance have gained much attention over the past decades. In light of cost considerations, less-expensive non-noble metal catalysts such as Ni-based catalysts have subsequently been examined due to their comparable activity to noble metals [4]. Obstacles for Ni-based catalysts to realize commercial application are metal sintering at high temperature and carbon deposition caused by two side reactions (Eqs. 2,3) during the CRM reaction [5]. Carbon aggregates on the surface of Ni when the particle size is larger than 7 nm and the accumulated carbon then covers the active sites, resulting in catalyst deactivation [6]. On this basis, research has been conducted to improve the resistance to sintering and carbon deposition of Ni-based catalysts by increasing metal dispersion and metal-support interaction (MSI). It has been demonstrated that support materials with a large specific surface area and excellent pore structure can achieve better metal dispersion [7]. Moreover, carbon materials have been increasingly applied in heterogeneous catalytic reactions as a catalyst or support in recent years [9]. For instance, Zhang et al. [10] focused on applying activated carbon catalysts in CRM with good results achieved. Compared to activated carbon, carbon fibers (CFs) have a similar thermal stability and high specific surface area, while their fibrous nature makes them attractive for producing catalysts with a well-defined structure [11]. The review by Gong et al. mentioned that one future development trend will be catalysts with well-defined structures, as controllable modification makes it easier to achieve catalyst-directed regulation for specific reactions [12]. In a previous study, we prepared Ni-based CFs and applied them to CO2/CH4 reforming [13] and H2O/CH4 reforming [14] with considerable initial activity achieved. Additionally, use of the CF decreased the activation energy of CO2 and notably improved CO2 conversion rates. Nevertheless, catalyst stability was poor due to partial consumption of the CFs through reaction with CO2 at high temperature [13]. To improve the stability of the CF-supported catalysts, studies were conducted which partially coated CFs with Al2O3 [13] to produce composite supported Ni catalysts. Catalytic activity was enhanced with inclusion of the metal oxides, illustrating the feasibility of using a composite support material. Yet, the morphology of the synthesized composite support was non-uniform, which directly limited the activity and stability of the as-prepared catalysts [15]. Of the three metal oxides considered, the nickel-based SiO2-coated CFs gave the best CRM activity and is consequently the focus of the study presented here. While the SiO2-coated CF-supported catalyst delivered an improved catalytic performance there exists the potential for even greater improvement by preparing a more regulated and uniform silica coating on the CFs. The work described here develops an approach to provide a uniform silica coating on CFs as a catalyst support for the CRM so as to minimize degradation of the CF during reaction and improve its stability. Additionally, utilizing silica as the metal oxide of choice enables an opportunity to form nickel phyllosilicate during the catalyst synthesis process. Ni phyllosilicates have been shown to be catalytically active for the CRM reaction [16,17] with the capacity for their formation in our catalyst system and their ensuing CRM activity/selectivity being examined. 2 Experimental 2.1 Material Tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS), HCl, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, HNO3, H2SO4 and ethanol were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Co., Ltd (Australia). Commercial CF was purchased from Shenbo Chemical Co., Ltd (Nanjing, China). The CF was pretreated with a concentrated mixture of HNO3/H2SO4 with a volume ratio of 3:1 before use. Ultrapure water with a resistance above 18 MΩ/cm was provided by a Milli-Q purification system (Branstead, USA). All gases used in experiments were provided by Coregas Co., Ltd (Australia), and include carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), helium (He), argon (Ar), hydrogen (H2) and nitrogen (N2) with a purity of at least 99.995 %. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Three separate catalysts, prepared by varying the order of SiO2 and Ni addition, were synthesized using a modified hydrothermal method with the synthetic scheme summarized in Fig. S1. Specifically, two precursor mixtures were first synthesized: (A) a suspension of 0.4 g CF in 15 mL of H2O, and (B) a solution of 4 mL TEOS in 10 mL of ethanol. SiO2Ni@CF was made by adding 0.2972 g of Ni(NO3)2·H2O to suspension A, then mixing with solution B and 1 mL of HCl (0.25 M). Ni@SiO2@CF was prepared by mixing suspension A with solution B and 1 mL of HCl, then drying and impregnating with a Ni(NO3)2·6H2O solution, as described previously [15]. SiO2@Ni@CF was synthesized by first impregnating the CF with Ni and then adding the TEOS solution and 1 mL of HCl. The three suspensions were treated for 30 min in an ultrasonic bath, then sealed in an autoclave and heated at 180 °C for 24 h. The obtained sample was washed with ultrapure water and ethanol by filtration before being dried at 105 °C. Finally, the recovered power was calcined at 550 °C for 2 h in an N2 atmosphere. As a comparison, a 5 wt% Ni/CF control sample (no silica) was prepared via the impregnation method, as described in a prior study [15]. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) was applied to detect the actual Ni content of the three catalysts. Briefly, 20 mg of sample powder was digested in mixed solution of HCl:HNO3 = 3:1 for 3 h and evaporated overnight at ambient temperature. The sample was then dispersed in 10 mL of ultrapure water with the resulting dispersion tested on a Perkin Elmer OPTIMA 7300. Surface area and pore size distribution of the calcined catalysts was determined by a Micrometrics Tristar 3000. The samples were degassed at 280 °C under vacuum for 6 h prior to analysis. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) of the calcined catalysts was performed using an attenuated total reflectance Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (ATR-FTIR; Spotlight 400 FTIR, PerkinElmer) in the wavelength range of 650 cm−1∼4000 cm−1. H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) analyses were conducted on an AutoChem 2920 equipped with a Thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Approximately 30 mg of sample was pretreated at 300 °C in an Ar atmosphere for 90 min to remove surface impurities. The sample was then heated from ambient temperature to 850 °C at a heating rate of 8 °C/min in a 5 % H2/Ar atmosphere, with the effluent gas monitored continuously during the heating process. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis of the catalysts was performed on a Thermo Scientific Escalab X-ray photoelectron spectrometer with an Al-Kα monochromator. To observe the Ni particle size over different samples, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) characterization was performed on a FEI Tecnai G20 filed-emission transmission electron microscope (FE-TEM) working at 200 kV of acceleration voltage. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was used to study the morphology of the catalysts on a NanoSEM 230. Crystallinity of the fresh and spent catalysts was examined using X-ray diffraction (XRD, PANalytical Xpert Multipurpose X-ray Diffraction System) with Cu-Kα radiation (λ=0.154 nm) at 45 kV and 40 mA from 10° to 80°. Raman spectra were acquired under ambient conditions on a micro-Raman spectrometer (Renishaw inVia confocal Raman microscope, UK) equipped with a 532 nm Ar-ion laser beam. 2.4 Catalyst testing Catalytic activity was evaluated over the temperature range of 600 °C–850 °C. A reactor (quartz, 6 mm ID) was loaded with 0.1 g of sample and the sample reduced at 600 °C in a 50 % H2/Ar atmosphere at a total flow of 60 mL/min for 2 h. Following reduction, the CRM test was performed using a reactant mixture of CH4/CO2/N2 = 1:1:1 (total flow: 60 mL/min), with the effluent gas passed into two separate gas chromatographs in parallel: (i) a Shimadzu 2010 (Japan) with a flame ionisation detector (FID) and HP-PLOT/U column for CH4, CO2, and CO detection; and (ii) a Shimadzu 8A with a TCD detector and Molecular Sieve 13 × 80/100 Washed column for H2 detection. Catalytic stability was conducted using the same reactor and same conditions at a constant temperature of 700 °C for 24 h. As a comparison, the stability of the 5 wt% Ni/CF was assessed at the same conditions. CH4 and CO2 conversions as well as H2/CO ratio were used to define catalyst performance and were calculated using the equations provided in the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characteristics of the SiO2/Ni-coated CF Elemental analysis of the samples after preparation shows that the Ni contents for SiO2Ni@CF, Ni@SiO2@CF, SiO2@Ni@CF are 3.2 wt%, 5.0 wt% and 1.5 wt%, respectively (Table 1 ). The discrepancy in Ni content, relative to the nominal loading of 5 wt%, may be attributed to the difficulty in digesting the SiO2 whereby any Ni species encapsulated or strongly bound by SiO2 may remain undetected. Physicochemical properties of the three calcined catalysts are summarized in Table 1 with the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm and pore size distribution profiles shown in Fig. S2. The surface area of all samples was lower than that of pure CF as shown in Table 1, demonstrating that the coating of Ni and SiO2 on the CF decreases the surface area. Notably, coating the CF with SiO2 then Ni, that is Ni@SiO2@CF, exhibits the highest surface area (1062 m2/g), although this may be indicative of poor coating of SiO2 and Ni on the CF surface. In general, catalyst morphology plays a significant role in catalytic performance. To observe the influence of the order of Ni and SiO2 addition to the catalyst performance of CF supported catalysts, TEM characterization was performed, with results shown in Fig. 1 . It can be seen from Fig. 1 that the coating of SiO2 and the loading of Ni are realized on all three catalysts with high dispersion achieved as a result of the large surface area and pore volume of the CFs [15]. SiO2Ni@CF and Ni@SiO2@CF both display a highly uniform coating on the CF support, while separate clusters of SiO2 are observed for SiO2@Ni@CF (Fig. 1e–f). To observe the overall coating states of the three catalysts, SEM characterization was carried out with the results shown in Fig. S4. From the EDS-elemental mapping images, it is clear that the surface of SiO2Ni@CF is more uniform than the other samples, where SiO2 and Ni are evenly loaded on the surface of the CF. It can be seen from the SEM image of Ni@SiO2@CF, which was coated first with SiO2 and then impregnated with Ni, that the SiO2 is partially agglomerated. Particularly, from the Ni-mapping image (Fig. S4e), the exposure of Ni species on the surface of Ni@SiO2@CF catalyst is high, supported by the more prevalent red colour. In contrast, the surface morphology of SiO2@Ni@CF is the least uniform when comparing all SEM images. This is clear in Fig. S4i whereby large portions of SiO2 do not coat the Ni@CF surface, instead forming distinct aggregates separate from the CF. As the CF used in this study comprises HNO3/H2SO4-modified fibers, oxygen-containing functional groups should be present on the surface [18]. During hydrolysis of the TEOS by HCl to form SiO2, the SiO2 is anchored on the surface of the CF by reacting with the oxygen-containing functional groups, thereby delivering a uniform coating [19]. When impregnating Ni on the surface of CF, ion exchange occurs between the oxygen-containing functional groups and Ni2+, which leads to Ni occupying the CF surface [20]. The accumulated silica may originate from stripping of the SiO2 from the CF surface, which may derive from a lack of sufficient oxygen-containing functional groups on the CF surface to bind SiO2, thus resulting in agglomeration of the SiO2. In addition, it can be seen from the Ni-mapping image in Fig. S4h that the active components of Ni are partially agglomerated. Structure, crystallinity and reducibility of fresh SiO2@Ni@CF, Ni@SiO2@CF and SiO2Ni@CF, were evaluated using FT-IR, H2-TPR and XRD with the results shown in Fig. 2 . As can be seen from Fig. 2a, the calcined catalysts exhibit infrared absorption bands located at 1042 cm−1 and 791 cm−1, which can be attributed to the symmetrical stretching vibration of SiOSi [21]. The bands indicate that SiO2 was grown on the surface of the CFs during the hydrothermal reaction. The adsorption band at 969 cm−1 is assigned to the stretching vibration mode of SiO− contained in the silanol group, which has been reported to participate in Ni phyllosilicate formation [22]. After calcination, only the SiO− stretching vibration band for SiO2Ni@CF disappears. This implies that more Ni phyllosilicate species have formed on the surface of the SiO2Ni@CF. Fig. 2b depicts the H2-TPR profiles of the calcined catalysts where two distinct peaks are apparent for each material. The lower temperature peak, located at 350 °C∼450 °C, corresponds to the reduction of NiO to metallic Ni° that is weakly bound to the CF surface [6]. The higher temperature peak, located at 550 °C ∼700 °C, is attributed to the reduction of NiO which interacts strongly with the CF support. The reduction profile of Ni@SiO2@CF exhibits NiO reduction peaks at lower temperatures (348 °C and 554 °C) but with larger intensities than SiO2@Ni@CF and SiO2Ni@CF. This signifies that the sample has the highest content of reducible Ni on the catalyst surface and that these Ni species have the weakest MSI. The reduction peaks for SiO2@Ni@CF appear at higher temperatures (420 °C and 635 °C). The higher reduction temperature is attributed to the reduction of Ni2+ in the 1:1 phyllosilicate structure [23]. With respect to SiO2@Ni@CF, the NiO is covered by dense and stable SiO2 during the coating process, which restricts NiO from contacting the H2, thus leading to the increase in reduction temperature. In addition, the contact between SiO2 and NiO formed during synthesis may lead to the introduction of new species such as Ni phyllosilicate, which enhances the MSI and increases the Ni reduction temperature [24]. The profile for SiO2Ni@CF displays even higher Ni reduction temperatures for this sample. The peak at 690 °C can be assigned to the reduction of Ni2+ in the 2:1 phyllosilicate structure [24], indicating that this sample possesses the strongest MSI. SiO2 and Ni species mixed and coated simultaneously on to the surface of the carbon fiber can react with each other forming Ni phyllosilicate during the hydrothermal process. Moreover, the width of the reduction peak is broader than for Ni@SiO2@CF, suggesting a better Ni dispersion over the catalyst and a lower Ni content relative to Ni@SiO2@CF. Overall, it can be concluded from H2-TPR results that Ni phyllosilicate formed during the synthesis of SiO2Ni@CF enhances the MSI. This is a key attribute as MSI is an important factor in preventing active metal species sintering at a high reaction temperature, thereby maintaining catalyst stability [12]. To further examine the crystal structure of each component in the reduced catalysts, XRD analysis was conducted with the associated patterns (after reduction at 600 °C) shown in Fig. 2c. All three catalysts exhibit an amorphous SiO2 diffraction peak at 22.1° [25]. The diffraction peak at this position may also be attributed to amorphous carbon from the CF, but the existence of SiO2 was confirmed by the earlier FT-IR and EDS mapping results. After reduction, peaks characteristic of Ni°, located at 44.5°, 51.9° and 76.6°, appear only for Ni@SiO2@CF. This indicates that most of the NiO on Ni@SiO2@CF was reduced to Ni, while a weak diffraction peak, located at 43.2°, shows the appearance of a small amount of NiO, probably due to the redox of Ni° to NiO in air before performing the XRD analysis. There are no Ni° diffraction peaks present in the XRD spectra of SiO2@Ni@CF and SiO2Ni@CF, with only NiO observed as indicated by the characteristic peak at 43.2°. Besides, the peak corresponding to NiO over SiO2Ni@CF is stronger than that of SiO2@Ni@CF, demonstrating the reduction difficulty of Ni species on SiO2Ni@CF at 600 °C (verified by H2-TPR). For the application of Ni based catalyst in CRM, the metallic Ni° is the active species whereas NiO has no activity during the whole reaction process and the well-dispersed smaller Ni particles may be ‘invisible’ to detection by XRD [26]. Thus, no Ni crystal size calculated for the three reduced catalysts. Notably, the characteristic peaks of the Ni phyllosilicate structure (Ni3Si2O5(OH)4) only appear for SiO2Ni@CF, present at 19.21°, 34.05° and 60.61° (PDF# 49-1859) [23]. The finding adds weight to the notion that the reduced SiO2Ni@CF contains a lamellar phyllosilicate structure which can protect the reduced Ni from sintering during reduction and thus decrease the particle size. XPS characterization was undertaken to examine the chemical states of the different elements in the calcined catalysts. The XPS analysis indicated the presence of C, O, Si, Ni, N (Fig. S3) in all samples, with the spectral regions for Ni2p and Si2p provided in Fig. 3 . The peak at a binding energy of 854.15 eV is only observed in the spectrum of Ni@SiO2@CF in Fig. 3c, representing the presence of NiO [27]. The lack of a NiO peak for SiO2@Ni@CF and SiO2Ni@CF is likely a result of SiO2 coating on the Ni species and formation of the phyllosilicate structure, respectively. The Ni2p spectrum of the calcined catalyst displays typical features indicative of paramagnetic Ni2+ species with satellite structures present due to the electron shake-up effect. The peaks observed in the region of 856.9 eV–858.6 eV likely represent the formation of Ni phyllosilicate, although there are only a few literature reports which provide XPS data for Ni phyllosilicates. Lehmann et al. [22] used the difference between Ni2p and Si2p binding energies, △ENi-Si, as an indicator for the Ni phyllosilicate species. The △ENi-Si for Ni@SiO2@CF, SiO2@Ni@CF and SiO2Ni@CF are 752.13 eV, 753.28 eV and 753.39 eV, respectively. According to Lehmann et al., 752.13 eV corresponds to 1:1 Ni phyllosilicate, while 753.28 eV and 753.39 eV correspond to 2:1 Ni phyllosilicate [22]. The reduction temperature of 1:1 Ni phyllosilicate should be lower than that of 2:1 Ni phyllosilicate, which is consistent with the H2-TPR results discussed above. By calculating the peak area, it is apparent that the level of Ni phyllosilicate formation in SiO2Ni@CF was significantly higher than for SiO2@Ni@CF and Ni@SiO2@CF, demonstrating the increased propensity for phyllosilicate formation when coating the Ni and SiO2 together. It has been pointed out [6] that when the particle size of Ni in a CRM catalyst is less than 7 nm, carbon deposits produced by CH4 cracking are reduced, thus catalytic activity could be maintained. To gain further insight into the particle morphology and Ni particle size, the catalysts were characterized by TEM after reduction at 600 °C for 2 h. The large diameter of the carbon fibers (> 5 μm) renders a calculation of particle size distribution difficult, so the Ni/SiO2 coating was separated from the CF support by increasing the ultrasonication time of the catalysts in acetone for 1 h before TEM characterization. The dispersion of Ni particles and corresponding size distribution are shown in Fig. 4 . The SiO2Ni@CF catalyst retains the layer-like Ni phyllosilicate structure after reduction, which indicates that the substance has not been completely reduced under the conditions used in this study. In addition, ultrafine Ni particles with an average size of 6.7 nm can be seen to be highly dispersed throughout the silicate structure. Partial preservation of the lamellar phyllosilicate structure guarantees Ni sintering resistance and thus a better dispersion of Ni°, which is beneficial for catalyst activity. In contrast, the presence of Ni phyllosilicates is not observed for Ni@SiO2@CF or SiO2@Ni@CF after reduction according to the TEM images. In the instance of SiO2@Ni@CF, Ni was first loaded on the surface of CF by impregnation, where the large specific surface area of CF (∼1300 m2/g) enables high active metal dispersion. SiO2 was then coated on the surface, encapsulating the Ni deposits to form a small amount of Ni phyllosilicate as a result (see XPS, Fig. 3). Near uniform Ni particles and amorphous SiO2 species were formed on the CF surface after reduction with the average Ni° size on SiO2@Ni@CF being 7.0 nm. In the case of Ni@SiO2@CF, SiO2 formed in the pores and occupied the active sites of the CF, leading to the decrease in surface area and pore volume, thus hampering Ni particle dispersion. In the context of the weak MSI exhibited by this catalyst, agglomeration during the reduction process is easy to envisage, with the largest average Ni particle size obtained (18.2 nm). 3.2 Catalyst performance The equilibrium constant of the CRM reaction increases exponentially with temperature, becoming very thermodynamically favored above approximately 700 °C [28]. To reveal the catalytic performance of SiO2@Ni@CF, Ni@SiO2@CF and SiO2Ni@CF before and after 700 °C, the CRM reaction over the three catalysts at a space velocity of 36000 mL/g.h and temperatures ranging from 600 °C ∼ 850 °C was assessed in terms of CH4 and CO2 conversion as well as the H2/CO ratio as shown in Fig. 5 a–c. Higher CH4 and CO2 conversion is achieved as the temperature is increased, demonstrating the endothermic nature of the CRM reaction. Across the entire temperature range, Ni@SiO2@CF delivers the best performance, with the CH4 conversion increasing from 37 % at 650 °C to 90 % at 850 °C. This may be attributed to greater active Ni exposure on the Ni@SiO2@CF surface relative to the other two catalysts, as suggested by the ICP-OES results. The conversion of CO2 at low temperatures is significantly higher than CH4 conversion over all three catalysts, and is supported by the low H2/CO ratios (Fig. 5c). This is attributed to the lower activation energy for CO2 decomposition than CH4 on the CF-supported catalysts, despite the fact that the CO2 decomposition could also be influenced by occurrence of the reverse water-gas shift reaction (CO2 + H2 → CO + H2O) [29]. Other reports have indicated that carbon deposition can be reduced at a high reaction temperature (>750 °C) as the side-reaction (Eq. 2) contributing mostly to carbon deposition is restricted [28]. To investigate the influence of carbon deposition on SiO2@Ni@CF, Ni@SiO2@CF and SiO2Ni@CF, stability testing of the three catalysts was performed at a temperature of 700 °C with the results shown in Fig. 5d, e. As a control, a stability test using 5 wt% Ni/CF (i.e. Ni-loaded CF without SiO2 coating) was also conducted under same conditions with the results shown in Fig. S5. The comparison with Ni/CF highlights a distinct improvement in catalytic stability with the addition of SiO2 to the CF. From Fig. 5d, the highest CH4 conversion rate (63 %) is displayed by Ni@SiO2@CF. This is attributed the Ni having been loaded onto the SiO2 surface for Ni@SiO2@CF, which didn’t allow for the formation of SiO2-coated Ni, thus resulting in a large exposure of active sites on the catalyst surface. Although the initial CH4 conversion rate of Ni@SiO2@CF is better than the other two catalysts, it decreases to 48 % over the 24 h reaction time-frame. The loss in activity may be attributed to the weak MSI causing catalyst deactivation via Ni sintering. Evidence supporting a weaker MSI can be found in the lower Ni reduction temperature of Ni@SiO2@CF in the H2-TPR results with the finding agreeing with other studies where Ni was impregnated on the SiO2 surface [29]. CH4 conversion by the SiO2@Ni@CF is the lowest among the three catalysts, with an initial value of 38 % decreasing to 15 % after 24 h. For this catalyst, the coated SiO2 film synthesized by HCl-promoted hydrolysis prevents the complete reduction of NiO, leading to a lower active site presence and catalyst deactivation. The low Ni content evidenced by ICP also reflects the coverage of NiO by the SiO2 film. These two effects together decrease the availability of active Ni sites, thereby limiting the overall catalyst activity. In the case of the SiO2Ni@CF catalyst, although the initial CH4 conversion (55 %) is slightly lower than Ni@SiO2@CF, it retains a comparatively high conversion (50 %) after 24 h. The stability of the SiO2Ni@CF stems from the strong MSI which is facilitated by formation of the Ni phyllosilicate during synthesis. Generally, a higher reduction temperature in the H2-TPR profile indicates stronger MSI, which is favorable for metal dispersion and the formation of smaller metallic Ni particles. This agrees with the characterization findings for SiO2Ni@CF whereby it displays the highest Ni reduction temperature and the smallest average Ni deposit size, as detailed earlier. In the present study, the catalysts were reduced at 600 °C for 2 h, with the H2-TPR for SiO2Ni@CF suggesting that the NiO may not be completely reduced at this temperature. Consequently, the slightly lower initial CH4 conversion but superior stability displayed by SiO2Ni@CF than Ni@SiO2@CF may be attributed to formation of the Ni phyllosilicate structure over the surface of the CFs. As shown in Fig. 5e, the initial CO2 conversion rates by the three catalysts are similar, approaching 90 % which are much higher than for the CH4 conversion. This is primarily ascribed to the CF support used in this study which can help reduce the activation energy of CO2 during the CRM reaction [13]. Concurrently, the presence of the reverse water-gas shift reaction could also contribute to the higher CO2 conversion [30]. Additionally, enhanced CO2 dissociation during the CRM is reported to be favorable for removing deposited carbon [31], highlighting the appeal of CF as a support. In similar fashion to the CH4 conversion, SiO2Ni@CF maintains a stable CO2 conversion after 24 h, illustrating the improvement delivered by coating silica and loading Ni within the same synthetic step. 3.3 Spent catalyst characteristics Characterization of the three fresh catalysts suggested that the MSI between the Ni and the coated carbon fiber was significantly influenced by the structure of the coated species, which varied upon changing the addition order of the precursors. The MSI influenced catalyst activity and stability, as Ni species which weakly interacted with the support were readily sintered, promoting catalyst deactivation. In addition to metal sintering, carbon deposition is also an important factor governing stability of the CRM catalysts. Carbon deposition on the catalyst surface was analyzed by XRD and Raman Spectroscopy with the results exhibited in Fig. 6 . From Fig. 6a, it can be seen that only the surface of Ni@SiO2@CF has a clear carbon diffraction peak, located at 26.1° [32], indicating coke formation. According to the Raman results in Fig. 6b, the smallest ID/IG is obtained for the spent Ni@SiO2@CF, where decreases in the ID/IG ratio indicate an increased degree of carbon graphitization. Further, the peak that appears at 2700 cm−1 is assigned to the existence of a ‘few-layer’ graphene species, which contributes to catalyst deactivation. As the support used in the study was carbon-based, Raman spectra of the three fresh catalysts were also obtained for comparison with the spent materials, with the results shown in Fig. S6. To discern the actual degree of graphitization of carbon species on the catalyst surface after the CRM reaction, the difference between ID/IG before and after reaction (△ID/IG) was used to explain coke formation on the three catalysts. Specifically, △ID/IG values of 0.071, 0.002 and 0.107 were calculated for SiO2@Ni@CF, Ni@SiO2@CF and SiO2Ni@CF, respectively. Comparing the △ID/IG illustrates that the carbon species on SiO2Ni@CF are dominated by disordered carbon, which can be easily eliminated during the reaction process, contributing to the high stability of the catalyst. SEM-EDS and TEM characterizations of the catalysts after the 24 h stability test was performed with the results provided in Figs. 7 and 8 . As can be seen from the Fig. 7 that the carbon fiber still maintains a good fiber structure after reaction for all the three catalysts. In addition to the SiO2Ni@CF, the carbon deposition on the other two materials increases significantly. In addition, the fold-like Ni phyllosilicate structure dominates the morphology of SiO2Ni@CF without deposited carbon. This suggests there is a confinement effect, arising from the partially unreduced phyllosilicate structure [16], imposed on the dispersed Ni0 (particle size 6.7 nm) when coated on the CF surface. Same results can be observed from the TEM images (Fig. 8). In the case of SiO2@Ni@CF, a small amount of Ni phyllosilicate is formed, which may arise from re-oxidation of the Ni during the reforming process. In addition, some fibrous carbon is produced, covering the active Ni0 via bottom-growth. This would be expected to gradually cover all the active Ni sites [33], likely accounting for the catalyst deactivation observed in Fig. 5. In the case of Ni@SiO2@CF, agglomeration of Ni0 on the catalyst surface occurs due to the weak MSI, as previously indicated by the H2-TPR results. This leads to the production of large amounts of fibrous carbon through the tip-growth mechanism, where the Ni is dislodged from the support material by the carbon filaments but remains active during the CRM reaction [34]. Carbon accumulation around the larger Ni0 illustrates the importance of the active particle size. Consequently, the increased Ni0 particle size for Ni@SiO2@CF and SiO2@Ni@CF relative to SiO2Ni@CF may have also contributed to formation of the fibrous carbon. It has been demonstrated that when the MSI is weak, carbon deposits will follow the tip-growth mechanism [34]. However, for many catalysts, as the specific surface area of the support is small, the reactor might be rapidly blocked due to carbon deposition, resulting in a rapid decrease in activity [35]. The CFs used in this study minimize this problem with their fluffy nature and large specific surface area providing possibilities for the formation of carbon deposits through tip growth. This shows consistency with the XRD results in Fig. 7, further demonstrating that the Ni0 particle aggregates on Ni@SiO2@CF provide a condition which favors the formation of carbon deposits. According to previous reports, the carbon deposits produced during dry gas reforming usually undergo a transformation process, whereby those initially formed are able to be eliminated to yield CO [35]. Generally, carbon deposits that are not rapidly removed via oxidation will gradually transform into graphitized carbon, and will accumulate and grow at the active sites, thus leading to catalyst deactivation [34]. Based on an overall consideration of the characterization results for the spent catalysts, possible mechanisms for carbon deposition on the three catalysts are proposed, as described in Fig. 9 . In the case of SiO2Ni@CF, uniform Ni phyllosilicate structures were formed on the CF support surface during catalyst preparation. A large number of these lamellar phyllosilicate structures remained after reduction (Fig. 4a), which helped to stabilize the Ni0 particles via a confinement effect. Consequently, there is a reduction in metal sintering with better catalyst stability during 24 h time on stream then being obtained. Additionally, the size of the active Ni particles on SiO2Ni@CF is below the threshold for carbon formation as suggested by Kima et al. [36]. Such complementary resistances to Ni0 sintering and carbon formation over SiO2Ni@CF deliver more stable activity over the 24 h reaction period. Utilizing CF as a support is conducive to the dissociation of CO2, resulting in the re-oxidation of Ni0 by O* produced from the CO2 dissociation [13]. This may be apparent for SiO2@Ni@CF, where a small amount of Ni phyllosilicate formed on the surface after the reaction suggests that Ni0 re-oxidation may have occurred, which invokes a loss in activity. In addition, the carbon on SiO2@Ni@CF is predominantly fibrous in nature, emerging via a bottom-growth mechanism on the surface of large Ni0 particles. The accumulating carbon aggregates on the surface of the active Ni sites, leading to the unwanted catalyst deactivation. For the Ni@SiO2@CF, although all the Ni species on the surface are converted to Ni° during reduction, the Ni° undergoes agglomeration at high temperature due to the weak MSI. The size of the enlarged particles exceeds the limit (18 nm versus ∼7 nm) of carbon deposition, resulting in Ni@SiO2@CF undergoing the severest carbon deposition among the catalysts. The carbon deposits here mostly grow via the tip-growth mechanism. Rather than covering the Ni° active sites, the carbon deposits lift the Ni0 catalyst from the CF surface. This allows the Ni sites to remain viable, thereby maintaining their activity over the 24 h reaction period. Although the carbon deposits generated by tip-growth will not affect the activity of Ni@SiO2@CF in the short term, the continuous formation of fibrous carbon will ultimately block the reactor, leading to a sharp decline in activity. This effect is somewhat off-set by the high surface area of the carbon fiber (> 1300 m2/g), giving sufficient space for the growth of fibrous carbon without reactor blockage. 4 Conclusion In this study, three different Ni-based silica-coated CF catalysts, namely Ni@SiO2@CF, SiO2@Ni@CF and SiO2Ni@CF, were prepared by a modified hydrothermal method and used in the CRM reaction. The preparation of catalysts with different structures was realized by changing the order of silica and Ni coating on the CF. Notably, the activity and stability of SiO2Ni@CF was found to be the greatest for the CRM at 700 °C, over a 24 h reaction period. This was attributed predominantly to the nature of the interaction between Ni and SiO2 during the hydrothermal coating process which promoted the formation of highly dispersed Ni phyllosilicate on the CF surface. The presence of the phyllosilicate structure improved the MSI via a confinement effect, thus enhancing the sintering resistance of the active Ni° particles and improving catalyst stability. Moreover, it’s difficult for Ni phyllosilicate to be reduced, leading to a decrease in the Ni particle size to ∼6 nm, thus improving the carbon deposition resistance. Overall, it is demonstrated that a resistance to high-temperature sintering by Ni-based catalysts can be enhanced by forming a well-defined Ni phyllosilicate structure on a high surface area CF support. The strategy is also considered to be suitable for other reactions using similar metal-based catalysts which are often prone to sintering, such as those used in the methanation reaction. coredata.dc:description: Silica-coated carbon fibers were prepared via a modified hydrothermal method with three separate catalysts synthesized by changing the sequence of Ni and SiO2 precursor addition to the carbon fiber and the as-prepared catalysts were utilized in the CO2 reforming methane reaction. It is found that the addition order of SiO2 and Ni precursors governed catalyst performance, where the addition of Ni and SiO2 precursors simultaneously (SiO2Ni@CF) has led to high stability for long-term operation at 700 °C. Particularly, CO2 conversion rate over SiO2Ni@CF catalyst was maintained at approximately 85 % after 24 h. The superior performance of SiO2Ni@CF is attributed to the formation of Ni phyllosilicate species. Simultaneous Ni-SiO2 addition facilitated a decrease in the particle size of the active Ni deposits via a confinement effect. The confinement effect constrained the reduced Ni particles to a lamellar phyllosilicate structure which introduced greater activity and an enhanced resistance to metal sintering.
coredata.dc:title: Inducing Ni phyllosilicate formation over a carbon fiber support as a catalyst for the CO2 reforming of methane
